I **believe** the trespassing signs are just there to give legal cover to the land owner in case someone does try to sue them.

Here are two sources that essentially support my beliefs:

[General definition](https://www.law.cornell.edu/wex/trespass):

> Trespass is defined by the act of knowingly entering another person’s property without permission.

[More detailed legal definition](https://www.law.cornell.edu/cfr/text/25/11.411):

> § 11\.411 Criminal trespass.
> 
> 
> (a) A person commits an offense if, knowing that he or she is not licensed or privileged to do so, he or she enters or surreptitiously remains in any building or occupied structure. An offense under this subsection is a misdemeanor if it is committed in a dwelling at night. Otherwise it is a petty misdemeanor.

As you can see these buildings are clearly owned by someone, and you clearly haven't gotten permission to enter the building. Ergo, you're trespassing.

Now if you were talking about ancient Mayan ruins, or an Old West ghost town then this would be more of a gray area, I believe, since those structures have been abandoned for 150\+ years. The same goes for structures in National Parks, since a National Park is *public* land you could make a case that you thought you were allowed to go since you *weren't specifically told* you can't go (assuming you didn't cross a fence line/no trespassing sign). You should definitely contact a real lawyer though.

---

Now if you do enter then I think the probability that you will be caught and prosecuted would be fairly low. It is your decision if that risk is worth the reward of entering/exploring the structure.

20.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the given information:

Question: According to the information provided, which of the following statements is most accurate regarding urban exploration (urbex) of abandoned buildings in the United States?

A) Entering abandoned buildings is legal as long as there are no "No Trespassing" signs posted.

B) Exploring abandoned structures is always legal if the explorer doesn't damage anything and leaves no trace.

C) Entering abandoned buildings without permission is likely considered trespassing, regardless of the presence of warning signs.

D) Urban exploration is only illegal if the building has been abandoned for less than 150 years.

Correct Answer: C

Explanation: The answer is C because the information provided suggests that entering abandoned buildings without permission is likely considered trespassing in the United States, regardless of whether there are warning signs present. The general legal definition of trespass is "knowingly entering another person's property without permission." The presence or absence of "No Trespassing" signs is primarily to provide legal protection for the property owner rather than to determine if entry is allowed. Options A and B are incorrect as they misinterpret the legal status of entering abandoned properties. Option D is also incorrect, as the 150-year timeframe mentioned in the text was only referring to very old structures like Mayan ruins or ghost towns, which might be considered a gray area, not a definitive legal threshold.

documentation.title: Can I use copyrighted media for strictly personal use?
documentation.text:
\#\#\# User: I know copyright / author's rights definition. I read bunch of texts about them and I am also aware that, for example, there are a kind of tolerance on YouTube about uses of copyrighted media (ex: songs' covers, remixes...) but even if they are tolerated, it is still not legal. But Youtube is a platform for sharing.

My question is : What about personal use of a copyrighted media ?

I searched on Internet but it is always about diffusion of such content, not personal use. In the strict aspect of law, would I be allowed to, for example, remix copyrighted songs just for my own usage, listening to them in my headphones ?

My first opinion would be no, as a copyrighted media covers :

* the right to reproduce the copyrighted work
* the right to prepare derivative works based upon the work
* the right to distribute copies of the work to the public
* the right to perform the copyrighted work publicly
* the right to display the copyrighted work publicly

It would be creating a derivative work of a copyrighted media, so it would be infringement, right ? Also, using a copyrighted music to put it on my vacation videos and showing it to my family only would be, law speaking, a copyright infringement, right ?

If that so, are every people drawing famous characters or playing famous music songs on their instrument, for training or just for fun, without any public diffusion, doing copyright infringement ?

By extension, are those doing public diffusion (ex: artists doing fanart of a video game character which is copyrighted) also doing copyright infringement ? Or is it considered as fair use ?

I got a bit lost when a friend ask me questions about that aspect of law.

Thanks !

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: Fair Use is what is called an "Active Defense" meaning that as a defendant in a copyright suit, you can use Fair Use as a defense, but it will not be assumed unless you specifically say such. To that end, fair use boils down to several factors of your work, such as the nature of your use of the derivative work (who did you show it to and for what purposes), the damage to the original copyright (usually monetary damages, but reputation damages or brand damage as well), and the derivative nature of the work (how is the message of the original work changed by your addition). Note that Quality of the work is never in question.

21.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the information provided:

Question: An aspiring musician creates a remix of a popular copyrighted song, adding their own beats and vocals. They share this remix with a small group of friends at a private gathering. Which of the following statements is most accurate regarding the legal status of this situation?

A) This is clearly fair use because it's not being publicly distributed or monetized.
B) This is definitely copyright infringement, regardless of the private nature of the sharing.
C) This could potentially be considered fair use, but it would need to be argued in court if challenged.
D) As long as the original artist is credited, this use is automatically protected under copyright law.

Correct Answer: C

Explanation: The correct answer is C. Fair Use is an "active defense" in copyright law, meaning it's not automatically assumed but must be argued if challenged. In this scenario, several factors would be considered to determine if it qualifies as fair use:

1. The nature of the use (private sharing with friends)
2. The potential market impact on the original work (likely minimal in this case)
3. The transformative nature of the remix

While the private nature and lack of monetization work in favor of fair use, it's not a guarantee. The remix is still a derivative work of copyrighted material. If challenged, the creator would need to argue fair use in court, considering all relevant factors. Options A and B are too absolute, while D is incorrect because crediting the original artist doesn't automatically make it legal.

documentation.title: What to do when an Ambulance can't pass you?
documentation.text:
\#\#\# User: So here's the deal: Earlier I was driving on the highway to work, which currently is under construction work. Because of that, one of the two lanes is closed and the second one is slightly narrowed. There is no emergency lane either. Then their was this ambulance driving right behind me, with sirens on and blue light flashing, so it surely was an emergency. In situations like that, as a driver, you obviously drive to the side and let the ambulance pass. However, because of the construction work this simply was not possible.

**What is the right thing to do in such a situation?** Is there anything written down in law (maybe the Straßenverkehrsordnung).

I tried to speed up a little to at least make it through constructions quicker. But the drivers in front of me didn't, so that was pretty much useless. 

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: §38 StVO Wegerecht

You are required to make way when practible

* i. e. within the rules of the StVO
* it is assumed that a driver does not have the needed overview to correctly access the situation

If nothing else is possible, infringements are tolerated. 

A driver should note date, time and (where practical) ambulance number, so that if a fine is sent (red light, stop line etc.) it can be cancelled due to an emergency which takes higher priority.

From your description you did everything possible \[you can't force the other to go faster].

Flashing light once to catch the attention of the driver in front may have been possible, but they may have had someone in front of them as well.

22.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the provided documentation:

Question: You are driving on a highway under construction with narrowed lanes and no emergency lane. An ambulance with sirens and flashing lights approaches from behind. What is the legally correct action according to §38 StVO Wegerecht?

A) Speed up significantly, even if it means breaking the speed limit, to clear the way for the ambulance as quickly as possible.

B) Stop immediately in your lane to let the ambulance pass, as safety is the top priority.

C) Continue driving normally, as there's nothing you can do in this situation without breaking traffic rules.

D) Make way if practicable within the rules of the StVO, and if not possible, continue driving safely while noting the date, time, and ambulance number if visible.

Correct Answer: D

Explanation: According to §38 StVO Wegerecht, drivers are required to make way for emergency vehicles when practicable and within the rules of the StVO. In situations where it's not possible to make way without breaking traffic rules, drivers should continue driving safely. The law recognizes that drivers may not have a full overview of the situation. If any traffic violations occur due to making way for an emergency vehicle, drivers should note the date, time, and ambulance number (if possible) to contest any potential fines. Option D correctly reflects this legal guidance, emphasizing safe driving within the rules while acknowledging the presence of the emergency vehicle.

documentation.title: Public school liability for slip and fall injury?
documentation.text:
\#\#\# User: If someone slips and falls on a patch of ice in a public school parking lot, and:

* The victim is not a student
* The victim was expected to be on the school grounds (i.e. not a "surprise visit" or a "wanderer")
* It occurred on a school day during school operating hours.
* The patch of ice was not salted
* The school should have known that salt should have been applied, due to obvious weather conditions (and they did, since other parts of school property were salted)

is the school liable for the medical bills incurred as a direct result of the injury?

I've researched this online, but almost every article I find speaks only about the school's responsibility to protect its students from injury. I can find very little about the law in the case of a visiting adult non\-student.

If the school IS liable, how do I go about collecting? I've already asked the school, and they basically said "no, thank you".

Not sure if it matters, but this particular case is in north\-east Ohio.

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: A few key points:

* The only way you can recover anything is with a lawsuit or the threat of a lawsuit.
* There are special procedural and substantive hurdles involved in suing a governmental entity which is a specialized area of tort law that varies significantly from state to state.
* It is likely that there is liability under a governmental waiver of the default rule of sovereign immunity in a case like this one, but it is also likely that special notices, court procedures and damages limitations apply to lawsuits brought to obtain this relief. For example, punitive damages are probably barred and other damages may be limited.

The primary statute relevant to a case like this one in Ohio is Ohio Revised Statutes §§ 2744\.01\-2744\.11, a chapter which is entitled "Political Subdivision Tort Liability". ORS § 2744\.02(B)(4\) states (in the pertinent part) that:

> \[P]olitical subdivisions are liable for injury, death, or loss to
>  person or property that is caused by the negligence of their employees
>  and that occurs within or on the grounds of, and is due to physical
>  defects within or on the grounds of, buildings that are used in
>  connection with the performance of a governmental function . . . .

ORS § 2744\.03(A) provides for a variety of defenses, most of which involve rogue employees, but one of which, (A)(5\), provides that:

> The political subdivision is immune from liability if the injury,
>  death, or loss to person or property resulted from the exercise of
>  judgment or discretion in determining whether to acquire, or how to
>  use, equipment, supplies, materials, personnel, facilities, and other
>  resources unless the judgment or discretion was exercised with
>  malicious purpose, in bad faith, or in a wanton or reckless manner.

There is an unusually strict form of two year statute of limitations set forth at ORS § 2744\.04\. The damages limitations are set forth at ORS § 2744\.05\. The liability and process for suits involving government employees is set forth at ORS § 2744\.07\. There are definitions at ORS § 2744\.01 which mostly have the usual and ordinary meaning in the context of your fact pattern. Special procedures govern payment of judgments in cases like these if they are awarded. ORS § 2744\.06\.

Of course, like any other civil action, once a suit is commenced in a timely fashion by a lawyer in the proper court, there is a good chance that it will be settled before going to trial.

Substantively, the main question before the trier of fact at trial (states vary on the right to a jury trial in suits against them and I don't know what the rule is in Ohio) are as follows:

1. Did the school district (if the school district indeed owned the parking law) have a duty to use reasonable care to keep the parking lot free of ice?
2. Was the school district negligent (i.e. did it breach its duty to use reasonable care through its actions)?
3. Was this negligence the cause of the harm suffered?
4. What dollar amount is necessary to compensate the victim for the harm caused by the negligence, subject to the applicable damages limitations?

Other provisions govern how the public subdivisions are insured, and generally, in Ohio, the school district would be a separate entity with its own liability arrangements and insurance, and not under the town or municipality as @Cicero suggests in his answer. The way school districts are organized relative to other local governments where he lives is different than the way that it is organized in Ohio.

23.answer:
Here's a multi-choice question based on the given information:

Question: In a slip-and-fall case against a public school in Ohio, which of the following statements is most accurate regarding the legal process and potential liability?

A) The school is automatically liable for all medical bills if the incident occurred during school hours and the victim was expected to be on school grounds.

B) The victim can only recover damages if they can prove the school acted with malicious intent or in bad faith.

C) The case would be governed by Ohio Revised Statutes §§ 2744.01-2744.11, with potential liability under § 2744.02(B)(4), subject to defenses and limitations outlined in the statute.

D) The victim has up to 5 years to file a lawsuit against the school district under standard personal injury statutes of limitations.

Correct Answer: C

Explanation: Option C is correct because it accurately reflects the legal framework for such cases in Ohio. The case would indeed be governed by Ohio Revised Statutes §§ 2744.01-2744.11, which deal with Political Subdivision Tort Liability. Specifically, § 2744.02(B)(4) provides a basis for potential liability, while other sections outline possible defenses, damages limitations, and procedural requirements.

Option A is incorrect because automatic liability is not guaranteed, even under the described circumstances. The school's negligence would need to be proven.

Option B is too restrictive. While malicious intent or bad faith could negate certain defenses, it's not the only way to recover damages. Negligence could be sufficient.

Option D is incorrect because the statute specifically mentions a strict two-year statute of limitations (ORS § 2744.04), not five years.

documentation.title: Cut off from a easement right of way through severance? 1.0.3 Division of Dominant
documentation.text:
\#\#\# User: I've made a little video of my question since I think its best drawn out to understand my question fully.

I will try to explain it quickly via words but best to review my video.

There was a parcel of land in Ontario. An entire 200 concession lot. Lets call it Parcel A. At some point Parcel A was divided in half. Creating a new Parcel B being the south half of Parcel A leaving the balance of Parcel A as north half.

During the severance of Parcel A it became subject to a right of way for the owners of Parcel B in, over along and upon a strip of land of a uniform perpendicular width of 25 feet being the easterly 25 feet of the north half Parcel A. The purpose was that the north half has a public road running through it which connects to the 25 foot right of way. Giving the owners of Parcel B a way to cross Parcel A and get to the public road.

Later on Parcel B was then split in half. Making a new Parcel C as the north half of B. Leaving the balance (the south half Parcel B) I know that in 1\.0\.3 Division of Dominant Lands it says "Upon the severance of a parcel of land, all existing easements appurtenant to the whole, benefit each severed portion." But how does Parcel B cross Parcel C when C is in the middle to get to the Right of way on Parcel A. Is it implied through law that B must have to cross C to get to A or has B now been landlocked? If its implied what law or wording in the law would support this? What path would the owner of B be allowed to take across C to get to the right of way on A?

See my short video <https://photos.app.goo.gl/WLxt8ixfHsiWbB1q7>

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: You don't identify a jurisdiction or what Section 1\.0\.3 you are referring to in the body of your question, and I didn't watch the video. I answer under the majority rules of U.S. common law.

> Is it implied through law that B must have to cross C to get to A or
> has B now been landlocked? If its implied what law or wording in the
> law would support this? What path would the owner of B be allowed to
> take across C to get to the right of way on A?

Under common law rules in most U.S. states, an **easement by necessity** would be implied in law for the owner of Parcel B to access their property from the public road across Parcel C to get to Parcel A. In a court action to have this easement by necessity recognized (if necessary), any reasonable route chosen by the owner of Parcel B across Parcel C would probably be recognized by the court.

Under some circumstances (such as the existence of an established path from Parcel B across Parcel C established by historic use) an **easement implied in fact** could also arise in the place where access was historically present prior to subdivision.

If an access route was used post\-subdivision for the requisite number of years without express permission to do so, and without legal action or a physical interruption of the access route, a **prescriptive easement** could arise (which is analogous to gaining title to land by adverse possession).

You could probably also sue the lawyer handling the subdivision for malpractice for forcing you to incur litigation costs, and delays causing other harm litigating an issue that should have been resolved with an express easement from Parcel B across Parcel C in the original transaction.

UPDATE: Upon later getting a chance to view the video, it seems that Ontario law is implicated. Ontario has codified real estate law to a much greater extent than most U.S. states, so I don't know if the common law doctrines found in the U.S. would apply to supplement Ontario law in this case.

If they don't, it is likely that a **private condemnation action** would be available under Ontario law, which is analogous to an eminent domain petition by a government with condemnation power to involuntarily purchase someone else's land for a public purpose at fair market value, but brought by a private landlocked land owner for the limited purpose of buying an access easement.

24.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the given information:

Question: In Ontario, a parcel of land (Parcel A) was divided into two parts, with the south half becoming Parcel B. Parcel B was granted a right of way over the eastern 25 feet of the north half of Parcel A to access a public road. Later, Parcel B was split in half, creating Parcel C as the north half of B. What is the most likely legal remedy for the owner of the south half of Parcel B to gain access to the public road?

A) An easement by necessity implied by common law
B) A prescriptive easement established through long-term use
C) A private condemnation action under Ontario law
D) Suing the subdivision lawyer for malpractice

Correct Answer: C

Explanation: 
While options A and B are common remedies in U.S. common law, the question specifically mentions Ontario. Ontario has codified real estate law to a greater extent than most U.S. states, so common law doctrines may not apply. Option C, a private condemnation action under Ontario law, is likely the most appropriate remedy in this jurisdiction. This would allow the landlocked owner to purchase an access easement at fair market value.

Option D, while potentially viable, addresses the cause of the problem rather than providing a direct solution for access. Therefore, the private condemnation action (C) remains the most likely and direct legal remedy for gaining access to the public road in this Ontario-based scenario.

documentation.title: Are US employees able to work remotely while abroad?
documentation.text:
\#\#\# User: There has been an increase in employees working remotely while abroad, especially during/after COVID. [Sometimes without telling their bosses](https://www.businessinsider.com/meet-remote-workers-secretly-working-abroad-without-boss-knowing-2022-10). Is it legal for US employees to work (for a US company) remotely in another country for an extend period (a year or longer)? (Assume that the host country doesn't have any special laws that forbid foreigners from working remotely.)

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: I've done it, I know a number of people who have done it. There's no general rule regarding employer\-employee relations – if you have to physically clock in, then basically no, if you don't do job you can get fired and the employer might require you to be physically present in a certain location. Whether or not it is legal to "work" in another country depends on the laws of that country, but there is no recurring law to the effect that you cannot "do work" while in a foreign country without a work permit or the like. There *is* a general rule that you have to be permitted to reside in a country, if you intend to reside in a country, so a US citizen cannot generally pick an arbitrary country and decide that they want to live there for a couple of years, without asking permission from the host government.

There can be a complex relationship between the premise for getting a long\-term visa to reside for a year in another country, and the rationale for that stay, for example a student coming to the US for the purpose of study cannot decide that instead they want to work as a car salesman. A scam whereby you claim to be a student in some local college when in fact you are working remotely for a call center would run afoul of immigration laws as well. The main consideration is whether you are present in the country under one pretense but in fact are doing something very different, which may then be illegal, but that depends on the country\-particular laws.

Since you are not employed in that country, you (probably) are not subject to taxation of your regular income (i.e. if I go to Norway for a year and receive my US salary, I will not have to also pay Norwegian income tax on the US salary).

25.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the provided documentation:

Question: An American employee of a U.S.-based company decides to work remotely from Spain for 18 months without informing their employer. Which of the following statements is most accurate regarding the legal implications of this situation?

A) This arrangement is always legal as long as the employee continues to perform their job duties satisfactorily.

B) The employee is definitely breaking U.S. law by working abroad without notifying their employer.

C) The legality of this arrangement depends on various factors, including Spanish immigration laws, the employee's visa status, and the employer's policies.

D) The employee will be required to pay income tax to both the U.S. and Spain on their entire salary during this period.

Correct Answer: C

Explanation: The correct answer is C because the legality of working remotely from another country is complex and depends on multiple factors. As stated in the documentation, there's no general rule forbidding remote work from another country, but several legal considerations come into play:

1. The host country's immigration laws: The employee needs to ensure they have the proper visa or residence permit to stay in Spain for 18 months.
2. The nature of the stay: If the employee entered Spain under false pretenses (e.g., claiming to be a student while actually working), this could violate immigration laws.
3. The employer's policies: While not necessarily illegal, working from another country without informing the employer could violate company policies and potentially lead to termination.
4. Tax implications: While the employee likely wouldn't have to pay Spanish income tax on their U.S. salary, there could be other tax considerations depending on the specific circumstances.

Option A is incorrect because legality isn't solely determined by job performance. Option B is too absolute, as U.S. law doesn't explicitly forbid working abroad without notifying an employer. Option D is likely incorrect based on the information provided, which suggests that the employee probably wouldn't be subject to double taxation on their regular income.

documentation.title: Can a tax debt owed to an EU country cause me any trouble in another EU country?
documentation.text:
\#\#\# User: I have recently left my country (Greece) and moved to Germany. While I am employed and everything functions perfectly, I have some debts to Greece's tax collection bureau.

While I will be able to pay those debts in a couple of years, in the meantime, is this any cause for concern about my situation on Germany? Can this affect me in any way?

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: Yes. The European Enforcement Order is an explicit procedure for uncontested claims like this. That means no German court is involved (unlike Dale M's answer suggests). The Greek Court files an EEO, and this can be enforced directly in Germany without going through German courts again. That means you can face wage garrisons, bank account freezes etcetera.

26.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the provided information:

Question: A Greek citizen moves to Germany for work, leaving behind unpaid debts to the Greek tax collection bureau. Which of the following statements is most accurate regarding the potential consequences of these unpaid debts in Germany?

A) The debts are only enforceable in Greece and have no impact on the individual's financial situation in Germany.

B) German courts must review and approve any attempt by Greek authorities to collect the debt in Germany.

C) The European Enforcement Order allows Greek authorities to directly enforce debt collection in Germany without involving German courts.

D) The individual can only face consequences if they return to Greece, as debt collection across EU borders is not possible.

Correct Answer: C

Explanation: The correct answer is C. According to the information provided, the European Enforcement Order (EEO) is an explicit procedure for uncontested claims like tax debts. This allows the Greek authorities to file an EEO, which can then be enforced directly in Germany without the involvement of German courts. This means the individual could face consequences such as wage garnishment or bank account freezes in Germany for their Greek tax debts.

Option A is incorrect because the debts can indeed have an impact in Germany through the EEO. Option B is wrong because German courts do not need to review or approve the debt collection under the EEO system. Option D is false because debt collection across EU borders is possible through mechanisms like the EEO, and the individual can face consequences in Germany without returning to Greece.

documentation.title: Could a declaratory judgement be used to nullify the Texas abortion law?
documentation.text:
\#\#\# User: Could [TX SB8](https://legiscan.com/TX/text/SB8/id/2395961) (the controversial abortion law) be nullified by a declaratory judgement?

Suppose a would\-be abortion provider were to file suit against Texas Right To Life, who are running the [ProLifeWhistleblower.com](http://prolifewhistleblower.com/) website, arguing that SB8 is an effective ban on abortion and hence unconstitutional, and suppose that the court agrees and grants a declaratory judgement saying so.

This would block Texas Right To Life from suing an abortion provider under SB8, but it wouldn't stop any John or Jane Doe from suing, because they were not parties to the original suit.

Suppose there is a subsequent suit by John Doe against Planned Parenthood for an abortion in Texas. Could that lawsuit be dismissed on the grounds that Doe is identically situated to Texas Right To Life, and it is already established that such a suit cannot lead to an award of damages?

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: As Texas Right to Life has not (as far as I know) yet sued any person or provider under SB8, I don't think there would be any legal justification for naming them in a suit. Even if they could be named, this would still leave it open to anyone else to file a suit under SB8 (which is why SB8 was written as it is).

Suits currently in progress have taken the approach of suing state officials who would have to be or might be involved in any future SB8 suit. At the moment these suits have been allowed to go forward, but the list of defendants have been limited. Court clerks and state judges have been held to be off limits as defendants. We will have to see where the suits in progress go.

27.answer:
Here's a difficult multi-form question based on the provided information:

Question: In the context of challenging Texas SB8 (the controversial abortion law), which of the following statements is most accurate regarding potential legal strategies and their effectiveness?

A) Filing a declaratory judgment against Texas Right To Life would effectively nullify SB8 for all potential plaintiffs.

B) Suing state officials involved in potential SB8 cases is currently the most viable approach, though with limitations on who can be named as defendants.

C) A successful lawsuit against Texas Right To Life would create binding precedent preventing any individual from filing suits under SB8.

D) Court clerks and state judges are considered appropriate defendants in current lawsuits challenging SB8.

Correct Answer: B

Explanation: 
A is incorrect because a declaratory judgment against one organization wouldn't prevent other individuals from filing suits under SB8. 
B is correct as it reflects the current legal approach being taken, with suits against some state officials being allowed to proceed, albeit with limitations on who can be named as defendants. 
C is incorrect because even if Texas Right To Life were successfully sued (which is questionable given they haven't filed an SB8 suit), this wouldn't create binding precedent for all potential plaintiffs. 
D is incorrect because the documentation specifically states that court clerks and state judges have been held to be off limits as defendants in current challenges to SB8.

documentation.title: Is putting a warning enough to make your hacking software legal?
documentation.text:
\#\#\# User: I never wrote a license or a readme for a program.
This is my readme.txt inside the folder of the program that gets downloaded :

> ATTENTION: HACKING IS ILLEGAL USE THIS AT YOUR OWN GMAIL ACCOUNTS THE PROGRAM DEVELOPER IS NOT RESPONSIBLE FOR ANY DAMAGE CAUSED BY THE PROGRAM
> 
> 
> contact program Developer at example@gmail.com .
> 
> 
> ENJOY !

My program does illegal stuff but it can be used on yourself without inflicting any damage to others, I saw many other programs that can be used for illegal purposes but are published normally, for example: nmap, hydra and Jhon the ripper.

Is this enough to make it legal to publish? If not what should I do?

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: In many jurisdictions, it is possible to legally publish software which may aid in hacking. Consider the well\-known [OWASP WebGoat](https://owasp.org/www-project-webgoat/), a training program for computer security. If you consider yourself an ethical professional, take a look at the number of warnings they have peppered over their software, e.g. on the bottom of the linked page.

What is necessary in *your* jurisdiction depends on where you live, and you haven't disclosed that. In the worst case, "exporting" it might violate [arms control legislation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Export_of_cryptography_from_the_United_States#Current_status).

28.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the provided information:

Question: A software developer creates a program that can potentially be used for hacking purposes. Which of the following statements best describes the legal implications and recommended course of action for publishing such software?

A) Publishing software that can be used for hacking is always illegal, regardless of the developer's intentions or disclaimers.

B) Including a disclaimer stating that the developer is not responsible for damages is sufficient to make publishing the software legal in all jurisdictions.

C) The legality of publishing such software depends on the specific jurisdiction, and developers should research local laws and potentially include extensive warnings and disclaimers.

D) As long as the software can be used for legal purposes on one's own accounts, it is always legal to publish, similar to tools like nmap or John the Ripper.

Correct Answer: C

Explanation: The correct answer is C because the legality of publishing software that could potentially be used for hacking varies depending on the jurisdiction. As mentioned in the documentation, what is necessary in a developer's jurisdiction depends on where they live. The example of OWASP WebGoat demonstrates that it is possible to legally publish such software in some places, but with extensive warnings and disclaimers. 

Answer A is incorrect because some jurisdictions do allow the publication of such software under certain conditions. 

Answer B is overly simplistic and doesn't account for the varying laws across different jurisdictions. A simple disclaimer may not be sufficient in all cases.

Answer D is incorrect because while some hacking tools are published, their legality still depends on local laws and may require specific precautions or disclaimers. The ability to use the software legally on one's own accounts doesn't automatically make its publication legal everywhere.

documentation.title: If someone is busking on a corner and a drug crazed preacher comes along ranting about gospel in slurred speech is there any offence?
documentation.text:
\#\#\# User: Suppose the preacher cones along and asks the busker how long they'll be there for to which he replies 6pm, when the preacher then says that he'll also leave at six but then goes up to the next junction/block to blast his megaphone/siren, but then gradually creeps back toward the busker's spot encroaching on his sound and space, and also rendering the initial decent interaction pointless and moot, and responds hostile and inflammatorily to polite reasonable requests to respect each other and stay on the other block until 6:00, is there anything the police might do?

Does the needlessly obnoxious and antisocial manner in which they're behaving and clearly drugged intoxication create any kind of charge like disturbing the peace or something like that? Or antisocial behaviour? Many people gathered around the busker to express support and appreciation for him as well as disgust toward the preachers unnecessary disrespect.

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: 
> "Does the needlessly obnoxious and antisocial manner in which they're
> behaving and clearly drugged intoxication create any kind of charge
> like disturbing the peace or something like that?"

Probably. But you don't want to take the law into your own hands. Call the police and have them make the judgement. There is a lot of discretion involved; some police officers may simply tell the preacher to move on; others may detain him on public intoxication or being a nuisance, according to local and UK laws, as well as check for permits and licenses for street/public performances.

> Many people gathered around the busker to express support and
> appreciation for him as well as disgust toward the preachers
> unnecessary disrespect.

That's well within rights, as long as the behavior doesn't degrade into the same type(s) that the preacher is exhibiting and possibly be a nuisance or worse (i.s., assault) as per the law.

29.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the given information:

Question: In the scenario described, what is the most appropriate and legally sound course of action for the busker to take when faced with the preacher's disruptive behavior?

A) Physically confront the preacher and forcibly remove him from the area
B) Encourage the gathered crowd to verbally harass the preacher until he leaves
C) Call the police and allow them to assess the situation and take appropriate action
D) Increase the volume of his own performance to drown out the preacher's noise

Correct Answer: C

Explanation: Calling the police (option C) is the most appropriate and legally sound action in this situation. This allows law enforcement to make a professional judgment on whether the preacher's behavior constitutes a public nuisance, disturbing the peace, or public intoxication. It avoids potential legal issues that could arise from taking matters into one's own hands (options A and B) or escalating the situation (option D). The police have the authority and discretion to handle such situations, potentially asking the preacher to move on or even detaining him if necessary, based on local laws and the specific circumstances. This approach also maintains the busker's legal and moral high ground in the conflict.

documentation.title: Would a search engine be allowed to prioritize their content?
documentation.text:
\#\#\# User: I notice that when I type anything into google, google\-related searches appear first. I know this is probably not what's happening, but it begs the question, could a search engine prioritize its own products and services legally?

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: Due to [competition/antitrust laws](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Competition_law) it can be illegal, more so if the search engine is dominant in the market.

This has actually been realized in the EU where they [fined Google €2\.42 billion](http://europa.eu/rapid/press-release_STATEMENT-17-1806_en.htm) for abusing their market dominance and favouring their own [Google Shopping](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Google_Shopping) service in search results. For further information, that fine has been [specifically addressed on this site](https://law.stackexchange.com/q/19862/3209).

In the US, this has not yet come to such a dramatic penalty, but there have been investigations. The [FTC has investigated](https://www.wsj.com/articles/inside-the-u-s-antitrust-probe-of-google-1426793274) similar search results manipulation among other antitrust issues, but ultimately decided not to file a lawsuit as the changes to the search algorithms ["could be plausibly justified as innovations that improved Google’s product."](https://www.ftc.gov/news-events/press-releases/2013/01/google-agrees-change-its-business-practices-resolve-ftc) Following this inaction, as of November 2017, the state of Missouri is [also investigating Google](https://www.nytimes.com/2017/11/13/technology/missouri-google-investigation.html) on the same issue.

I'm not certain if manipulating search results on its own is illegal, but with market dominance (like what Google has), it certainly is.

30.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the provided information:

Question: A dominant search engine company is considering prioritizing its own products and services in search results. Which of the following statements most accurately reflects the legal implications of this action?

A) This practice is always legal as long as the company discloses it to users.

B) This practice is legal in the United States but illegal in the European Union.

C) This practice is likely to be considered illegal under competition/antitrust laws, especially if the company has market dominance.

D) This practice is entirely legal as search engines have full discretion over their algorithms.

Correct Answer: C

Explanation: The correct answer is C. As demonstrated by the EU's €2.42 billion fine against Google for favoring its own shopping service in search results, prioritizing a company's own products in search results can be considered an abuse of market dominance under competition/antitrust laws. This is especially true for companies with significant market share, like Google.

While the United States hasn't imposed such dramatic penalties, there have been investigations by the FTC and individual states, indicating that this practice is scrutinized under U.S. antitrust laws as well. The legality isn't absolute and depends on factors like market dominance and whether the changes can be justified as innovations that improve the product.

Answer A is incorrect because disclosure doesn't necessarily make the practice legal. Answer B is incorrect because while enforcement has been stronger in the EU, the practice can still be problematic under U.S. law. Answer D is incorrect because search engines, especially dominant ones, do not have unlimited discretion in manipulating search results if it harms competition.

documentation.title: Irish Passport through Great Grandparent
documentation.text:
\#\#\# User: Say the family tree looks like this:

```
Great Grandfather <- Born in what is now Northern Ireland
Grandmother <- Born in Britain
Mother <- Born in Britain
Son <- Born in Britain

```

From a cursory glance of the relevant legislation, the grandmother and mother would be eligible for Irish citizenship as a foreign born citizen but the Son would not.

However, if the Grandmother or mother were to choose to exercise their right and obtain their Irish citizenship, this would reduce the number of generations between the son and the last Irish citizen ancestor to less than two. Would the son then be able to claim Irish citizenship? Finally, does it make any difference if the Great Grandfather was born in what is now the North or the Republic?

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: There's an answer at [Irish Citizens Information](https://www.citizensinformation.ie/en/moving_country/irish_citizenship/irish_citizenship_through_birth_or_descent.html), complete with a chart.

First, it doesn't matter if the Irish ancestor was living in the Republic or in Northern Ireland.

However, the ancestral right only extends to grandchildren unless you were born after 2015\. Otherwise, your parent must have claimed Irish citizenship before you were born.

31.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the provided information:

Question: The Smith family is considering claiming Irish citizenship. Their family tree is as follows:

- Great-grandfather: Born in Belfast (now Northern Ireland) in 1920
- Grandmother: Born in London in 1950
- Father: Born in Manchester in 1980
- Son: Born in Birmingham in 2010

Which of the following statements is correct regarding the Son's eligibility for Irish citizenship?

A) The Son is automatically eligible for Irish citizenship due to his great-grandfather being born in Northern Ireland.

B) The Son can claim Irish citizenship if his grandmother obtains Irish citizenship before he does.

C) The Son is eligible for Irish citizenship only if his father had claimed Irish citizenship before the Son's birth.

D) The Son cannot claim Irish citizenship under any circumstances due to being born after 2005.

Correct Answer: C

Explanation: According to Irish citizenship laws, ancestral rights typically extend only to grandchildren of Irish citizens. However, for those born before 2005 (which includes the Son in this case), the parent must have claimed Irish citizenship before the child's birth for the child to be eligible. The fact that the great-grandfather was born in Northern Ireland doesn't affect this rule, as Irish citizenship laws treat Northern Ireland and the Republic of Ireland equally for these purposes. The grandmother or father obtaining citizenship after the Son's birth would not retroactively make the Son eligible. Therefore, the only way for the Son to be eligible is if his father had claimed Irish citizenship before the Son was born in 2010.

documentation.title: Can China use the archipelagic doctrine
documentation.text:
\#\#\# User: China has been constructing man\-made islands strategically placed on the perimeters of their so called nine\-dash line. The question is, can China invoke the archipelagic doctrine to strengthen their claim for these territories? 

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: No
--

[Archipelagic states](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Archipelagic_state) are legally defined by the UN. China isn’t one of them. There are a number of countries with veto power in the UN who would likely block China becoming one.

32.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the provided information:

Question: Which of the following statements best describes China's ability to use the archipelagic doctrine to strengthen its territorial claims in the South China Sea?

A) China can invoke the archipelagic doctrine for its man-made islands within the nine-dash line, as any country can claim archipelagic status for artificial islands.

B) China cannot use the archipelagic doctrine, as it is not legally recognized as an archipelagic state by the United Nations.

C) China can partially apply the archipelagic doctrine to its man-made islands, but only with the approval of neighboring countries.

D) China's status as a permanent member of the UN Security Council allows it to unilaterally declare itself an archipelagic state.

Correct Answer: B

Explanation: The correct answer is B. According to the information provided, archipelagic states are legally defined by the UN, and China is not one of them. The archipelagic doctrine cannot be invoked by China to strengthen its territorial claims in the South China Sea, regardless of its construction of artificial islands. Additionally, any attempt by China to be recognized as an archipelagic state would likely face opposition from other countries with veto power in the UN. Options A, C, and D are incorrect as they misrepresent the legal status of archipelagic states and China's ability to claim such status.

documentation.title: Can a government's open data license include a provision to not allow use that damages the "honor or reputation" of their agency as a moral right?
documentation.text:
\#\#\# User: Moral rights are protected under CC BY 4\.0 license and some countries are unable to revoke these rights in a license even if they want to.

However, the provision to not allow reuse in a way that dishonors the original data producer, misleads, etc. seems awfully vague. So vague, that a government could use such a clause to terminate somebody's right to use data simply because they do not agree with the way it was used.

Is this a protected moral right that can be included in a government's open data license and still fully meet the open definition?

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: No
--

Only individuals have moral rights so a government or a company cannot claim to have them.

They can, of course, require the licence to respect individuals moral rights and, like any contract, could have a general [non\-disparagement clause](http://www.businessdictionary.com/definition/non-disparagement-agreement.html).

Derogatory treatment is defined in the relevant law, for example, [s 195AJ](http://www9.austlii.edu.au/cgi-bin/viewdoc/au/legis/cth/consol_act/ca1968133/s195aj.html) of the *Copyright Act 1968* (Cth):

> "derogatory treatment" , in relation to a literary, dramatic or musical work, means:
> 
> 
>      (a)  the doing, in relation to the work, of anything that results in a material distortion of, the mutilation of, or a material alteration to, the work that is prejudicial to the author's honour or reputation; or
> 
> 
>      (b)  the doing of anything else in relation to the work that is prejudicial to the author's honour or reputation.

And the courts know how to interpret this (see [Fernandez v Perez \[2012] NSWSC 1242](http://www.mondaq.com/australia/x/265880/Copyright/Copyright+and+moral+rightsTake+it+personally)).

In any event, you only have a right to use the copyrighted work **in accordance with the licence**. There is no question of terminating your right, your right continues even when they are suing you for **your** breach of the licence.

That said, if the license is silent about moral rights *you still have to respect them*. If you don’t the individual can sue you.

33.answer:
Here's a difficult multi-form question based on the given information:

Question: A government agency releases a dataset under an open license that includes a clause prohibiting use that "dishonors the original data producer or misleads the public." A researcher uses this data to publish findings critical of the government's policies. The government claims this violates the license terms. Which of the following statements is most accurate regarding this situation?

A) The government can legally revoke the researcher's right to use the data based on this clause, as it's part of the license agreement.

B) The clause is invalid because governments cannot claim moral rights, but the researcher must still respect individual moral rights even if not explicitly stated in the license.

C) The researcher has absolute freedom to use the data as they see fit once it's released under an open license, regardless of any restrictive clauses.

D) The government can sue the researcher for breach of contract, but cannot terminate the researcher's right to use the data as long as they comply with other license terms.

Correct Answer: B

Explanation: 
The correct answer is B because:
1. Governments cannot claim moral rights, as these are reserved for individuals. Therefore, the clause attempting to prohibit use that "dishonors the original data producer" is not enforceable as a moral right when claimed by a government entity.
2. However, researchers and users of copyrighted works must respect individual moral rights even if they are not explicitly mentioned in the license. This is a separate obligation that exists regardless of the specific license terms.
3. Answer A is incorrect because the government cannot legally revoke rights based on a clause that attempts to claim moral rights it doesn't possess.
4. Answer C is incorrect because even under open licenses, users must comply with the valid terms of the license and respect moral rights.
5. Answer D is partially correct in that the government cannot terminate the right to use the data for compliant use, but it's not the most accurate answer because it doesn't address the invalidity of the government's claim to moral rights.

documentation.title: How are general damages for assault calculated?
documentation.text:
\#\#\# User: For example, in discrimination suits, one has the Vento scale as a guide to calculating damages. Does anything similar exist for trespass to person?

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: You are looking for the [*Judicial College Guidelines for the Assessment of General Damages in Personal Injury Cases*](https://global.oup.com/academic/product/guidelines-for-the-assessment-of-general-damages-in-personal-injury-cases-9780192867629?lang=en), which had its sixteenth edition published in April 2022\. This book sets out the range of compensation based on the type of injury suffered. The scale is very detailed. For example, we can find in Chapter 7,

> **(G) Injuries to the elbow**
>   
> (a) A severely disabling injury \- **£39170 to £54830**
>   
> (b) Less severe injuries causing impairment of function but not involving major surgery or significant disability \- **£15650 to £32010**
>   
> (c) Moderate or minor injury
>   
>  (i) Injuries fully resolving after about one year \- **In the region of £3530**
>   
> (ii) Injuries with the majority of symptoms resolving within 18 to 24 months but with nuisance level symptoms persisting after that \- **In the region of £6500**
>   
> (iii) Injuries recovering after three years with nuisance symptoms thereafter and/or requiring surgery \- **Up to £12590**

There are lots of other rules about the calculations, which are beyond what can be summarised in a text box. In the case of assault, one might find reference to Chapter 4, which is on psychiatric effects including PTSD, as well as to the physical injuries. Probably the most important note is that they are *Guidelines*, not *Rules*, and so the court can deviate from them at its pleasure. But this is what the judge will have at their fingertips during the proceedings.

Because these concern damages, receipt of an award will depend on whether the respondent actually has the money. For that reason, there is a statutory scheme, the [*Criminal Injuries Compensation Scheme*](https://www.gov.uk/guidance/criminal-injuries-compensation-a-guide), which can make additional payments to victims of violent crime. CICS awards are reduced based on civil damages already paid, because you can't be compensated twice for the same injury. They are also calculated after any insurance payout, so it's in the nature of a final resort.

The CICS tariffs are not the same as the JCG ones. Taking the elbow example, CICS 2012 rates damage to one elbow with substantial recovery at **£1500** (level A2\), and with continuing significant disability at **£6200** (level A7\). Other eligibility rules and procedures are different as well. In practice, the majority of CICS awards are for between £1000 and £2400 (bands A1 to A4\); there is a proposed simplification of the bands into fewer levels, but this has not yet been implemented.

34.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the given information:

Question: A 32-year-old man is assaulted, resulting in a severe elbow injury that causes significant disability and requires major surgery. The assailant is caught but has no assets. Which of the following statements is most accurate regarding potential compensation for the victim?

A) The victim can expect to receive between £39,170 to £54,830 from the Criminal Injuries Compensation Scheme, based on the Judicial College Guidelines.

B) The victim will likely receive £6,200 from the Criminal Injuries Compensation Scheme, as this is the amount specified for continuing significant disability to one elbow.

C) The victim can claim compensation from the Judicial College Guidelines and the Criminal Injuries Compensation Scheme simultaneously, potentially receiving over £60,000 in total.

D) The victim may be eligible for compensation through the Criminal Injuries Compensation Scheme, but the amount will likely be significantly less than what is suggested in the Judicial College Guidelines for similar injuries.

Correct Answer: D

Explanation: Option D is the most accurate statement. The Judicial College Guidelines suggest a range of £39,170 to £54,830 for severely disabling elbow injuries. However, these guidelines are primarily used for civil cases where the defendant has assets to pay damages. In this case, the assailant has no assets, making it unlikely the victim will receive this amount through a civil suit.

The Criminal Injuries Compensation Scheme (CICS) is designed for situations like this, where victims of violent crime can receive compensation. However, CICS awards are typically much lower than those suggested by the Judicial College Guidelines. The CICS tariff for an elbow injury with continuing significant disability is £6,200, which is considerably less than the civil guidelines suggest.

It's important to note that victims cannot be compensated twice for the same injury, so they cannot claim from both sources simultaneously (ruling out option C). Options A and B are incorrect because they misapply the guidelines or tariffs to the wrong compensation scheme.

Therefore, the victim is likely eligible for CICS compensation, but the amount will be significantly less than what the Judicial College Guidelines suggest for similar injuries in civil cases.

documentation.title: Can I leave my friend my body if I die
documentation.text:
\#\#\# User: So when I die I want my friend to keep my body parts in a jars and maybe make a mask out of my face or some thing like that. Can I do that? I’m only 17 so idk if my parents would have a say or if a will would even work for me being in parental control. Anyways thanks 

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: It depends on where you live. In Washington, [RCW 68\.50\.110](https://app.leg.wa.gov/RCW/default.aspx?cite=68.50.110) requires that

> Except in cases of dissection provided for in RCW 68\.50\.100, and where
>  human remains are rightfully carried through or removed from the state
>  for the purpose of burial elsewhere, human remains lying within this
>  state, and the remains of any dissected body, after dissection, must
>  be decently buried, undergo cremation, alkaline hydrolysis, or natural
>  organic reduction within a reasonable time after death.

Per [RCW 68\.50\.130](https://app.leg.wa.gov/RCW/default.aspx?cite=68.50.130),

> Every person who performs a disposition of any human remains, except
>  as otherwise provided by law, in any place, except in a cemetery or a
>  building dedicated exclusively for religious purposes, is guilty of a
>  misdemeanor. Disposition of human remains following cremation,
>  alkaline hydrolysis, or natural organic reduction may also occur on
>  private property, with the consent of the property owner; and on
>  public or government lands or waters with the approval of the
>  government agency that has either jurisdiction or control, or both, of
>  the lands or waters.

So cutting the body up and sticking the bits in a jar is illegal, but cremating or dissolving it and keeping the remains in a jar is legal. 

As for parental permission, [RCW 68\.50\.160](https://app.leg.wa.gov/RCW/default.aspx?cite=68.50.160) says that

> A person has the right to control the disposition of his or her own
>  remains without the predeath or postdeath consent of another person. A
>  valid written document expressing the decedent's wishes regarding the
>  place or method of disposition of his or her remains, signed by the
>  decedent in the presence of a witness, is sufficient legal
>  authorization for the procedures to be accomplished.

It does not require that the person be an adult.

35.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the provided information:

Question: A 17-year-old in Washington state wants to specify in their will that their body should be preserved in jars after death. Which of the following statements is most accurate regarding the legality and feasibility of this request?

A) The request is fully legal and can be carried out exactly as specified, regardless of parental consent.

B) The request is illegal and cannot be carried out under any circumstances due to the minor's age.

C) The request can be legally carried out, but only if the body is first cremated or undergoes alkaline hydrolysis, and the resulting remains are then kept in jars.

D) The request requires parental consent to be legally binding, even if specified in a will.

Correct Answer: C

Explanation: According to Washington state law (RCW 68.50.110 and 68.50.130), it is illegal to keep human remains or body parts without proper disposition (burial, cremation, alkaline hydrolysis, or natural organic reduction). However, the law does allow for the keeping of remains after cremation or alkaline hydrolysis, including on private property with owner consent. Furthermore, RCW 68.50.160 states that a person has the right to control the disposition of their remains through a valid written document, regardless of age. Therefore, while the 17-year-old cannot legally request their body be preserved in jars as-is, they can specify that their remains be cremated or undergo alkaline hydrolysis and then kept in jars, without requiring parental consent.

documentation.title: Good Samaritan law
documentation.text:
\#\#\# User: What exactly is the Good Samaritan law? Can someone please explain the Good Samaritan law? What is the Good Samaritan statute? How would someone apply the law in LaSalle County Illinois?

Edit: After reading some comments and answers, how would this apply in a situation where you were trained for cpr/first aid, called assistance to someone threatening suicide, and ended up with charges against you for assisting by calling for aid? 

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: In [Illinois](http://www.ilga.gov/legislation/ilcs/ilcs3.asp?ActID=2076&ChapterID=58):

> The General Assembly has established numerous protections for the
>  generous and compassionate acts of its citizens who volunteer their
>  time and talents to help others.

Basically, if you are a licensed medical profession, or have had successful training in CPR provided by the the American Red Cross or the American Heart Association, and you try in good faith to save somebody's life and fail, you are not liable for their death, under the assumption you did not cause harm in the first place (i.e. you can not stab someone in the chest, attempt CPR, and be exempt from lawsuit(s)). 

Note that this doesn't apply to just CPR or physicians. This also covers dentists, Pharmacists, Optometrists, Physical Therapist, etc.

36.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the provided information:

Question: In LaSalle County, Illinois, a bystander with American Red Cross CPR certification attempts to perform CPR on an unconscious person in a public park. Despite their efforts, the person doesn't survive. Under the Good Samaritan law, which of the following statements is most accurate?

A) The bystander is automatically liable for the person's death because they intervened without being a licensed medical professional.

B) The bystander is protected from liability only if they can prove they performed CPR perfectly according to their training.

C) The bystander is protected from liability as long as they acted in good faith and did not cause the initial harm to the person.

D) The Good Samaritan law does not apply in this situation because the incident occurred in a public place rather than a medical facility.

Correct Answer: C

Explanation: The Illinois Good Samaritan law protects individuals who have received CPR training from organizations like the American Red Cross and who attempt to save someone's life in good faith. The law assumes that the person providing aid did not cause the initial harm. In this scenario, the bystander with American Red Cross CPR certification would be protected from liability for the person's death, as long as they acted in good faith and did not cause the initial harm that led to the person becoming unconscious. The law applies regardless of whether the incident occurred in a public place or a medical facility, and it does not require proof of perfect CPR execution, only that the person acted in good faith based on their training.

documentation.title: Self defense damages
documentation.text:
\#\#\# User: Someone attacks me. I punch them in self defense. During the punch I dislocate my shoulder.

Are there civil damages incurred when I injured myself in self defense and got a medical bill?

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: Yes
---

Assuming you were [assaulted](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Assault_(tort)) (with or without battery) and you suffered injury (physical or otherwise) during that assault you are entitled to damages. The injury has to flow from the assault but not necessarily from the assaulter. For example, if you fled across the road and were struck by a car you could sue your attacker.

Because assault is an intentional tort, it is not necessary for you to prove that actual financial loss was [suffered](https://websterslawyers.com.au/personal-injury-assaulted) \- this is not negligence. The court can assess economic loss, non\-economic loss and exemplary (punitive) damages.

37.answer:
Here's a multi-choice question based on the given information:

Question: John is attacked by a stranger in a parking lot. While defending himself, John throws a punch but accidentally dislocates his own shoulder in the process. He incurs $5,000 in medical bills for treatment. Which of the following statements is most accurate regarding John's potential civil claim against his attacker?

A) John cannot claim damages because he injured himself, not the attacker.
B) John can only claim damages for emotional distress, not physical injuries.
C) John can claim damages for his medical bills and other losses resulting from the dislocated shoulder.
D) John can only claim damages if he can prove the attacker intended for John to injure himself.

Correct Answer: C

Explanation: According to the information provided, in cases of assault (an intentional tort), the victim can claim damages for injuries that "flow from the assault but not necessarily from the assaulter." This means that even though John injured himself while defending against the attack, he can still claim damages for this injury because it occurred as a direct result of the assault situation. The correct answer is C, as John can claim damages for his medical bills and other losses resulting from the dislocated shoulder, even though he caused the specific injury himself while defending against the attack. Options A and B are incorrect because they unduly limit John's ability to claim damages. Option D is incorrect because it imposes an unnecessary requirement of proving the attacker's specific intent regarding John's self-injury, which is not necessary in assault cases.

documentation.title: Why was an American who overstayed in Singapore not caned?
documentation.text:
\#\#\# User: The US citizen Kamari Kenyada Charlton overstayed his visa while in Singapore. The [law](https://sso.agc.gov.sg/Act/IA1959#pr6-) is that this shall "be punished with caning with not less than 3 strokes".

However, according to [this story](https://www.asiaone.com/print/News/AsiaOne%2BNews/Crime/Story/A1Story20110221-264712.html), he was jailed 18 months for his telephone scam and seems to not have received any punishment for overstaying. Why?

More background:

* [*WSJ*, "U.S. Man Faces Caning in Singapore", Oct 20 2010](https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424052702304011604575564012145605090)
* [*WaPo*, "U.S. citizen faces possible caning in Singapore", Oct 22 2010](http://voices.washingtonpost.com/checkpoint-washington/2010/10/us_citizen_faces_possible_cani.html)"
* [Gopalan Nair, "Singapore. One law for some and another for others. The case of American Kamari Kenyada Charlton", Feb 21, 2011](http://singaporedissident.blogspot.com/2011/02/singapore-one-law-for-some-and-another.html)

---

The caning punishment is regularly enforced for overstayers from poor Asian countries (and also any who aid such overstayers):

* [*Channel News Asia*, "Foreign inmate diagnosed with COVID\-19 had arrived on Jan 10, sentenced to jail and caning on Jun 12 for overstaying", 20 Jun 2020](https://www.channelnewsasia.com/news/singapore/covid-19-changi-prison-inmate-overstaying-jail-12854542) (Sri Lankan)
* [*Yahoo News*, "Vietnamese man who overstayed in Singapore for over 10 years gets jail, caning", 2 April 2019](https://sg.news.yahoo.com/vietnamese-man-overstayed-singapore-10-years-gets-jail-caning-113447453.html)
* [*The Straits Times*, Indonesian gets two years' jail for attempt to sneak overstayer out of Singapore, Jul 8 2016](https://www.straitstimes.com/singapore/courts-crime/indonesian-gets-two-years-jail-for-attempt-to-sneak-overstayer-out-of)
* [*Today*, Man convicted for helping Bangladeshi overstayer: ICA, 28 March 2017](https://www.todayonline.com/singapore/bangladeshi-overstayer-arrested-after-attempting-leave-singapore-ica)

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: [Plea bargain](https://www.straitstimes.com/opinion/plea-bargaining-singapore-style)
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Probably.

Like all common law jurisdictions, Singapore practices plea bargaining. While not formalised as it is in the USA, a prosecutor can agree to drop certain charges and/or not pursue certain sentences in return for a guilty plea to others.

As it says in your link, the defendant “pleaded guilty to five charges last week.
17 other charges, including one for overstaying in Singapore, were taken into consideration.”

So, he was *not* convicted of overstaying his visa.

38.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the given information:

Question: In the case of US citizen Kamari Kenyada Charlton who overstayed his visa in Singapore, why was he not caned as prescribed by Singapore law for visa overstayers?

A) Singapore does not enforce caning punishments for visa overstayers from Western countries
B) Charlton was granted diplomatic immunity due to his US citizenship
C) The law requiring caning for visa overstayers was repealed before Charlton's case
D) Charlton likely agreed to a plea bargain where the overstaying charge was dropped in exchange for pleading guilty to other charges

Correct Answer: D

Explanation: The correct answer is D. The information provided suggests that Charlton likely entered into a plea bargain with the prosecutors. This is supported by the fact that he "pleaded guilty to five charges last week" and "17 other charges, including one for overstaying in Singapore, were taken into consideration." In Singapore's legal system, like other common law jurisdictions, prosecutors can agree to drop certain charges (such as overstaying) in exchange for a guilty plea to other charges. This practice explains why Charlton was not caned for overstaying, as the charge was likely dropped as part of the plea agreement.

Option A is incorrect because there's evidence that Singapore does enforce caning for visa overstayers from various countries. Option B is incorrect as there's no mention of diplomatic immunity, which is typically reserved for diplomats, not ordinary citizens. Option C is incorrect because there's no information suggesting the law was repealed, and other cases show it's still enforced for overstayers from other countries.

documentation.title: On the Term "Commercial Use" and the Usage of an Apparently Free Font
documentation.text:
\#\#\# User: I am in the process of finishing up a book which I anticipate will be published in the United States.

For the book's cover, I would like to make use of a font that is freely downloadable; and, *as far as I can tell*, does not forbid commercial use. In this case, I would like to make use of a font available from [https://www.schäffel.ch/de\_gruppe1\.html](https://www.xn--schffel-7wa.ch/de_gruppe1.html).

Now, I say, "as far as I can tell", for German is not my native language, and although I did not determine that "commercial use" is forbidden, I also did not detect anything along the lines of "free for commercial use."

QUESTION: Would using a freely downloadable font for a book to be published be considered as "commercial use"; and if so, may I legally use a font in that book **(without reprisal)** from a foreign site, which again, "as far as I can tell", does not seem to forbid it?

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: [https://www.schäffel.ch/allgemein\_de.html](https://www.xn--schffel-7wa.ch/allgemein_de.html):

> *"Die Fonts dürfen für private und professionelle Zwecke unbeschränkt verwendet werden. Sie kommen vollständig und mit allen Einbettungsrechten. Es wird gebeten, jegliche Modifikation der Datensätze, den Vertrieb unter anderen Namen, die Verteilung auf anderen Websites als dieser oder die Eingliederung in Font\-Pakete zu unterlassen."*

That is,

> The fonts may be used without restriction for private and professional purposes. They come complete and with all embed rights. Please refrain from any modification of the data sets, distribution under other names, distribution on websites other than this one or incorporation into font packages.

39.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the provided information:

Question: An author is planning to use a freely downloadable font from a German website for their book cover, which will be published commercially in the United States. Based on the website's terms (translated from German), which of the following statements is correct regarding the use of this font?

A) The font can be used for the book cover, but the author must pay a licensing fee for commercial use.
B) The font cannot be used for commercial purposes and is restricted to personal use only.
C) The font can be used for the book cover without restriction, as long as it is not modified or redistributed.
D) The font can only be used if the author obtains explicit written permission from the website owner.

Correct Answer: C

Explanation: The correct answer is C. The website's terms state that "The fonts may be used without restriction for private and professional purposes." This includes commercial use, such as a book cover. The terms also specify that the fonts come "complete and with all embed rights." However, users are asked to refrain from modifying the font, distributing it under other names, or incorporating it into font packages. Therefore, the author can use the font for their book cover without restriction, as long as they don't modify it or redistribute it.

Option A is incorrect because there is no mention of a licensing fee for commercial use. Option B is wrong because the terms explicitly allow both private and professional (which includes commercial) use. Option D is incorrect because the terms already grant permission for use without needing additional explicit permission.

documentation.title: Dating corporate banking resolution
documentation.text:
\#\#\# User: I've started a US / California corporation for my company and have almost instantly come up to an issue I do not know how to address.

In order to open a Bank account, the board (just me) has to agree to open an account with XYZ bank and to resolve to open that account. That resolution needs to be part of the meeting minutes.

My problem is, the bank I'm opening an account with let me know that they have their own resolution that they need signed that needs to become a part of my meeting minutes, but they do not provide this document until *after* the bank account is opened.

I'm in a "what came first, the chicken or the egg" scenario. *I can't open an account without a resolution but I didn't get a resolution document until after the account was opened.*

The resolution document provided by the bank states things such as "we resolved to open an account with XYZ bank at a meeting held on \_\_\_\_\_\_\_". 

So \- Do I back date this to before the account was opened or do I use today's date and have to hold another board meeting (with myself)?

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: So here is what the bank is looking for:

Your Board of Directors (BoD) has a meeting at some point. As part of that meeting, they (you) decide to open a bank account with XYZ Bank and pass a resolution (which is basically a "we will do this" which is voted on and passed by a vote). 

Now you send a representative to the bank to open the account. The bank wants to know that the company has passed a resolution to open the account with that particular bank. This helps protect them from an accountant just opening an account without the company knowing and embezzling money.

So the bank provides you a paper asking you to affirm that the resolution was passed, you just need to have that filled out and signed by a company signatory (usually the company secretary) that identifies the date that the resolution has passed. Some banks will require signatures from the members themselves, it just depends on the bank.

So the bank isn't asking you to pass a resolution to open the account, they are just asking you to confirm that one was passed at some point in the past. The "resolution document" isn't a resolution itself, just a confirmation of one.

40.answer:
Here's a multi-choice question based on the given information:

Question: A newly formed California corporation needs to open a bank account. The bank requires a board resolution to open the account, but also provides its own resolution document after the account is opened. What is the correct procedure for the corporation to follow?

A) Backdate the bank's resolution document to before the account was opened to avoid discrepancies.

B) Hold two separate board meetings - one before opening the account and another after receiving the bank's resolution document.

C) Open the account without any resolution and add the bank's document to the next board meeting minutes.

D) Hold a board meeting to pass a resolution to open the account, then use the bank's document as confirmation of this pre-existing resolution.

Correct Answer: D

Explanation: The correct procedure is to hold a board meeting and pass a resolution to open an account with the specific bank before actually opening the account. The document provided by the bank after opening the account is not the resolution itself, but rather a confirmation of the pre-existing resolution. This document should be filled out with the date of the original board meeting where the resolution was passed. This approach satisfies the bank's requirement for board approval without creating any legal or procedural issues.

documentation.title: Rental Issues - HMO was never issued by landlord (UK) & Notice Period after AST expiration
documentation.text:
\#\#\# User: Back in late 2016, three people rent a brand new flat in London (UK). Then, during the years, we had a few contract renewals (AST) with new names (as we had one person being replaced every year). 

This September, before our AST expired, one person got replaced and this time the agency didn't send us to sign an AST renewal.
